PIONEER DEPT.: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the pioneer's record of our province.

Name: Mrs. Wilfred
Address: Washburne
Birthplace: Washburne

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1914
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Washburne
   Where have you been living before that? Washburne
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 9
   How far was it to your nearest store? About 2 miles each
   How often could a visit be made to the store? About once a month
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, salt, coffee, tea, butter, eggs, milk, meat, vegetables, fruit, canned goods, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Red Star
   In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs. at a time
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50
   How much did you use graham flour? 20 lbs.
   Whole wheat flour? 20 lbs.
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? 20 miles
   What other grain products did you use? Oats, cornmeal, rice, beans, lentils
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
   How did you grind it? With a hand mill
